data.title: Famous Birthdays on April 21
data.meta_description: Famous birthdays for the 21st of April. See which celebrities, historical figures, scientists and criminals were born on April 21.
data.text:
Birthdays 1 - 200 of 212

Ulrich von Hutten, German knight, scholar and poet (led Imperial Knights against Roman Catholic Church), born in Schlüchtern, Hesse (d. 1523)

Arcangelo Crivelli, Italian composer, born in Bergamo, Republic of Venice (d. 1617)

Ludovico Carracci, Italian painter, born in Bologna, Papal States (now Italy) (d. 1619)

Jan van Riebeeck, Dutch colonial administrator and founder of Cape Colony (Cape Town), born in Culemborg (d. 1677)

Joseph Vaz, Oratorian priest and missionary in Ceylon, born in Benaulim, Goa, Portuguese India (d. 1711)

Michel Rolle, French mathematician (Rolle's theorem), born in Ambert, Basse-Auvergne (d. 1719)

John Law, Scottish economist and author (Money and Trade Considered), born in Edinburgh, Scotland (d. 1729)

Johann Philipp Käfer, German composer, born in Schney, Prince-Bishopric of Bamberg, Holy Roman Empire (d. 1728)

Wilhelmine Amalia of Brunswick-Lüneburg, Holy Roman Empire Empress, born in Hanover, Germany (d. 1742)

Louis de Noailles, Marshal of France, born in Versailles, France (d. 1793)

Catherine the Great

German-born Empress of Russia (1762-96) who expanded the Russian empire, born in Stettin, Kingdom of Prussia

Johann Michael Malzat, Austrian composer, born in Vienna, Austria (d. 1787)

Jean-Baptiste Biot, French physicist (Biot-Savart law), born in Paris (d. 1862)

Alexander Anderson, American engraver and illustrator (Shakespeare), born in New York City (d. 1870)

William Knyvett, British singer and composer, born in Westminster, London (d. 1856)

Vincenzo Pallotti, Italian saint (founder of the Society of the Catholic Apostolate), born in Rome (d. 1850)

Levin Minn Powell, American Commander (Union Navy), born in Winchester, Winchester City, Virginia (d. 1885)

Peter van Schendel, Dutch-Belgian painter (Monsieur Chandelle), born in Terheijden, Netherlands (d. 1870)

Robert M. T. Hunter, American lawyer and politician (2nd Confederate States Secretary of State), born in Loretto, Virginia (d. 1887)

John Putnam Chapin, American politician and 10th Mayor of Chicago (1846-47), born in Bradford, Vermont (d. 1864)

Alson Sherman, American politician (8th Mayor of Chicago 1844-45), born in Barre, Vermont (d. 1903)

Angela Burdett-Coutts, English philanthropist extrordinaire and "the richest heiress in England", born in London (d. 1906)

1814 Béni Egressy, Hungarian composer, librettist, and actor, born in Kazincbarcika, Hungary (d. 1851)

Charlotte Brontë

English novelist (Jane Eyre), born in Thornton, West Yorkshire, England

Louis Wigfall, American politician (Confederate States Senator from Texas 1862-85), born in Edgefield, South Carolina (d. 1874)

Hannibal Goodwin, Episcopal priest who patented a method for making film used in Thomas Edison's Kinetoscope, born in Taughannock, New York (d. 1900)

Anselmo Clavé, Spanish politician and composer, born in Barcelona, Spain (d. 1874)

Hippolyte Taine, French philosopher and historian (Voyage in Italy), born in Vouziers, Ardennes, France (d. 1893)

William Rufus Terrill, American Brigadier General (Union Army), born in Covington City, Virginia (d. 1862)

Fredrik Bajer, Danish politician, feminist and pacifist politician (Nobel 1908), born in Næstved, Denmark (d. 1922)

John Muir

Scottish naturalist and discoverer (glaciers in High Seirras), born in Dunbar

Ted Barratt, English cricket spin bowler (10-43 in tour match vs Australia 1878; MCC, Surrey CCC), born in Stockton-on-Tees, England (d. 1891)

Oskar Hertwig, German embryologist (discovered fertilization), born in Friedberg, Germany (d. 1922)

Charles Barrois, French geologist and palaeontologist, born in Lille, France (d. 1939)

Charles Malherbe, French violinist and composer, born in Paris (d. 1911)

Eusapia Palladino, Italian spiritual medium, born in Minervino Murge, Apulia (d. 1918)

1854 William Stang, German Roman Catholic Bishop, born in Bad Schönborn, Germany (d. 1907)

1854 Władysław Rzepko, Polish composer, born in Piórków, Poland (d. 1932)

Max Weber

German sociologist, economist and historian (Ancient Judaism), born in Erfurt, Province of Saxony, Prussia

Robert Herrick, American novelist (Common lot), born in Cambridge, Massachusetts (d. 1938)

Edwin S. Porter, American film pioneer and producer (Jack and the Beanstalk), born in Connellsville, Pennsylvania (d. 1941)

Leo Blech, German composer and conductor, born in Aachen, Rhenish Prussia (d. 1958)

1871 Vojtěch Říhovský, Czech composer, born in Dub nad Moravou, Bohemia, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1950)

Billy Bitzer, American cinematography pioneer, born in Roxbury, Boston, Massachusetts (d. 1944)

Albert Weisgerber, German painter and graphic artist, born in Sankt Ingbert, Germany (d. 1915)

Kartini, Indonesian national heroine, born in Jepara, Central Java, Dutch East Indies (d. 1904)

Jules-Marie Canneel, Flemish painter and caricaturist (Rocks of Oran), born in Brussels, Belgium (d. 1953)

Percy Williams Bridgman, American physicist (Nobel 1946 - physics of high pressure), born in Cambridge, Massachusetts (d. 1961)

Charles "Charlie" Naughton, Scottish actor (Frozen Limits), born in Glasgow, Scotland (d. 1976)

Joe McCarthy

American Baseball Hall of Fame manager (Chicago Cubs; New York Yankees - World Series 1932, 36–39, 41, 43; Boston Red Sox), born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania

Lillian Walker [Wolke] American silent era actress and film producer (An Embarrassment of Riches), born in Brooklyn, New York (d. 1975)

Efrem Zimbalist Sr, Russian-American violinist, composer, and educator (Curtis Institute, 1928-68), born in Rostov on Don, Russia (d. 1985)

1889 Paul Karrer, Swiss organic chemist (Nobel 1937), born in Moscow, Russia (d. 1971)

František Suchý, Czech composer and folk song collector, born in Březové Hory, Bohemia, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1973)

Jaroslav Kvapil, Czech composer, born in Fryšták, Bohemia, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1959)

Henry de Montherlant, French novelist and stage author (La Reine Morte), born in Paris (d. 1972)

Steve Owen, American Pro Football Hall of Fame tackle (NY Giants) and coach (NFL C'ship 1927, 34, 38; NY Giants), born in Cleo Springs, Oklahoma (d. 1964)

Clement D'Hooghe, Belgian composer, born in Temse, Belgium (d. 1951)

1899 Randall Thompson, American composer (Trip to Nahant), born in New York City (d. 1984)

Julián Bautista, Spanish orchestral and film score composer, and conductor, born in Madrid, Spain (d. 1961)

Ben Stroman, Dutch writer (Jomtof & Blue Beard), born in Rotterdam, Netherlands (d. 1985)

Hans Hedtoft, 14th Prime Minister of Denmark (1947-50, 53-55), born in Århus, Denmark (d. 1955)

Gijs van Hall, Dutch politician and Mayor of Amsterdam (1957-67), born in Amsterdam (d. 1977)

Edmund Gerald "Pat" Brown, American politician and Governor of California (D: 1959-67), born in San Francisco, California (d. 1996)

Tom Burns, British-Chilean publisher and editor, born in Chile (d. 1995)

Antoni Szałowski, Polish-French composer (The Resurrection of Lazarus; 2 Pieces for Ondes Martenot), born in Warsaw, Poland (d. 1973)

1907 Beatrice Kay, American singer and actress (Sister Sue-Calvin & Col), born in New York City (d. 1986)

Louis Hostin, French weightlifter (Olympic gold 1932, 36), born in Saint-Étienne, France (d. 1998)

Rollo May, American psychologist (Love & Will), born in Ada, Ohio (d. 1994)

Ivan Combe, American inventor of personal care products (Clearasil), born in Fremont, Iowa (d. 2000)

1911 Leonard Warren [Warenoff], American baritone (Metropolitan Opera, 1939-60) who died on stage, born in The Bronx, New York City (d. 1960)

Eve Arnold, American photojournalist (Marilyn Monroe), born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania (d. 2012)

1912 Feike Asma, Dutch organist and conductor, born in Den Helder, Amsterdam, Netherlands (d. 1984)

1912 Marcel Camus, French film director (Orfeu Negro), born in Chappes, France (d. 1982)

1913 Norman Parkinson, English fashion photographer (Harper's Bazaar), born in London (d. 1990)

Norman Panama, American screenwriter (d. 2003)

Andor Kovach, Romanian composer (Médée), born in Transylvania, Hungary, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 2005)

Anthony Quinn

Mexican-American actor (Zorba the Greek, Lawrence of Arabia, Lust for Life), born in Chihuahua, Mexico

1915 Emanuel Vardi, Israeli-American viola virtuoso and conductor (South Dakota Symphony 1978-82), born in Mutasarrifate of Jerusalem, Ottoman Empire (d. 2011) [1]

1915 Werner Groebli, Swiss ice skating clown, (Frick in ice skating act Frick & Frack), born in Basel, Switzerland (d. 2008) [1]

Sidney Clute, American actor (Lou Grant; Cagney & Lacey), born in Brooklyn, New York (d. 1985)

Don Cornell [Luigi Varlaro], American pop singer (Sammy Kaye Orchestra - "Room Full of Roses; solo - "Hold My Hand"), born in The Bronx, New York City (d. 2004)

1919 Frank Essed, Surinamese politician and forestry scientist (Operation Grasshopper), born in Paramaribo, Suriname (d. 1988)

1919 John Goddard, West Indian cricket all-rounder and captain (27 Tests @ 30.67; 33 wickets; Barbados), born in St Michael, Barbados (d. 1987)

1919 Roger Doucet, French Canadian tenor, noted for his bilingual rendition of national anthem "O Canada" at Montreal sporting events, born in Montreal, Quebec (d. 1981)

Bruno Maderna, Italian conductor, and avant garde composer (Quadrivium; Satyricon), born in Venice, Kingdom of Italy (d. 1973)

1920 Christopher Dark [Alfred Francis DeLeo], American character actor, (World Without End; The Time Tunnel), born in New York City (d. 1971)

1920 Edmund Adamkiewicz, German soccer forward (2 caps; Hamburger SV, Eintracht Frankfurt), born in Hamburg, Germany (d. 1991)

Jack Fletcher, American actor (Calucci's Department, Once Upon a Mattress), born in Forest Hills, New York (d. 1990)

Allan Watkins, Welsh cricket all-rounder, (15 Tests, England @ 40.15, 11 wickets; Glamorgan), born in Usk, Wales (d. 2011)

John Mortimer, English barrister, screenwriter and author (A Voyage Round My Father), born in London, England (d. 2009)

Daniel Melnick, American television and film producer (Get Smart; Ages of Man; Roxanne), and studio executive, born in New York City (d. 2009)

1924 Ira Louvin [Loudermilk], American country singer and mandolin player (Louvin Brothers - "The Only Way Out (Is to Walk Over Me)"), born in Section, Alabama (d. 1965)

Arthur Rowley, English soccer forward (most goals in English league football, 434 from 619 games; Leicester City, Shrewsbury Town), born in Wolverhampton, England (d. 2002)

Elizabeth II

Queen of the United Kingdom of Great Britain & Northern Ireland (country's longest reigning monarch 1952-2022), born in London

Gerald Flood, British actor (Doctor Who, Patton), born in Portsmouth, Hampshire, England (d. 1989)

Morgan Wootten, American Basketball Hall of Fame coach (46 seasons DeMatha Catholic HS, Hyattsville, Maryland; National C'ships 1962, 65, 68, 78, 84), born in Durham, North Carolina (d. 2020)

Angela Mortimer

British tennis player (French C'ships 1955, Australian C'ships 1958, Wimbledon 1961), born in Plymouth, England

1932 Elaine May, American comedienne, writer and actress (New Leaf, Primary Colors), born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania

1932 Slide Hampton [Locksley Wellington Hampton], American jazz trombonist, composer and arranger, born in Jeanette, Pennsylvania (d. 2021)

Ian Carr, Scottish jazz musician (Nucleus), born in Dumfries, Scotland (d. 2009)

Martin Horton, cricketer, England off-spin all rounder, 2 Tests 1959)

Charles Grodin, American stage and screen actor (Heartbreak Kid; Midnight Run; Ishtar: Beethoven series), writer, and talk show host, born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania (d. 2021) [1]

1935 Robin Dixon, England, 2 man bobsled (Olympic gold 1960)

American hockey HOF center (Olympic gold 1960; Harvard University), born in Cambridge, Massachusetts

1936 James Dobson, American evangelist

1937 David Lucas, American rock and roll composer, music producer and singer, born in Buffalo, New York

Helen Prejean, American writer

1939 John McCabe, British composer and pianist, born in Liverpool, England (d. 2015)

Souleymane Cisse, director (Waati, Yeelen, Finye, Baara)

American singer and lyricist known as "The Godfather of Punk" (The Stooges - "I Wanna Be Your Dog"; solo - "Lust For Life"), born in Muskegon, Michigan

1951 Michael Hartley Freedman, American mathematician
